microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Share your experiences in the comments. ğŸ”ğŸ’¬hashtag#EmailScam hashtag#JobScam hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#CareerFraud hashtag#ResumeScam hashtag#ATSScam hashtag#StayAware hashtag#LinkedInCommunity

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Share your experiences in the comments. ğŸ”ğŸ’¬hashtag#EmailScam hashtag#JobScam hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#CareerFraud hashtag#ResumeScam hashtag#ATSScam hashtag#StayAware hashtag#LinkedInCommunity

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Share your experiences in the comments. ğŸ”ğŸ’¬hashtag#EmailScam hashtag#JobScam hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#CareerFraud hashtag#ResumeScam hashtag#ATSScam hashtag#StayAware hashtag#LinkedInCommunity

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Share your experiences in the comments. ğŸ”ğŸ’¬hashtag#EmailScam hashtag#JobScam hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#CareerFraud hashtag#ResumeScam hashtag#ATSScam hashtag#StayAware hashtag#LinkedInCommunity

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Share your experiences in the comments. ğŸ”ğŸ’¬hashtag#EmailScam hashtag#JobScam hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#CareerFraud hashtag#ResumeScam hashtag#ATSScam hashtag#StayAware hashtag#LinkedInCommunity

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Share your experiences in the comments. ğŸ”ğŸ’¬hashtag#EmailScam hashtag#JobScam hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#CareerFraud hashtag#ResumeScam hashtag#ATSScam hashtag#StayAware hashtag#LinkedInCommunity

Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Microservice Roadmap Creating a roadmap for implementing microservices architecture involves several key phases and considerations.Microservice RoadmapPhase 1: Assessment and Planning1.Understand Business Goals:âœ…ï¸Identify the business objectives that the microservices architecture will support.âœ…ï¸Engage stakeholders to gather requirements and expectations.2.Evaluate Current Architecture:âœ…ï¸Assess the existing system architecture.âœ…ï¸Identify pain points and limitations of the monolithic system.3.Define Success Metrics:âœ…ï¸Establish KPIs to measure the success of the microservices implementation.4.Skill Assessment:âœ…ï¸Evaluate the current teamâ€™s skills in microservices, DevOps, and cloud technologies.âœ…ï¸Identify training needs or hiring requirements.Phase 2: Design and Strategy5.Define Service Boundaries:âœ…ï¸Identify logical boundaries for microservices based on business capabilities.âœ…ï¸Use domain-driven design (DDD) principles to guide service decomposition.6.Select Technology Stack:âœ…ï¸Choose appropriate languages, frameworks, and tools for developing microservices.âœ…ï¸Consider containerization (e.g., Docker), orchestration (e.g., Kubernetes), and cloud platforms.7.Design APIs:âœ…ï¸Define API contracts (REST, gRPC, GraphQL) for communication between services.âœ…ï¸Ensure APIs are versioned and follow best practices.8.Establish Data Management Strategy:âœ…ï¸Decide on data ownership for each service.âœ…ï¸Choose between shared databases and database per service patterns.Phase 3: Development and Implementation9.Set Up CI/CD Pipeline:âœ…ï¸Implement continuous integration and continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipelines for automating builds and deployments.10.Develop Microservices:âœ…ï¸Start building microservices iteratively, focusing on high-priority services first.âœ…ï¸Follow best practices for coding, testing, and documentation.11.Implement Service Discovery:âœ…ï¸Choose a service discovery mechanism (e.g., Eureka, Consul) to facilitate communication between services.12.Establish Monitoring and Logging:âœ…ï¸Implement centralized logging (e.g., ELK Stack) and monitoring (e.g., Prometheus, Grafana) for observability.Phase 4: Testing and Quality Assurance13.Automated Testing:âœ…ï¸Develop unit, integration, and contract tests for microservices.âœ…ï¸Implement service virtualization for testing inter-service interactions.14.Load and Performance Testing:âœ…ï¸Conduct load testing to ensure services can handle expected traffic.15.Security Assessment:âœ…ï¸Implement security best practices, including API security (OAuth2, JWT) and service-to-service authentication.ğŸ’¡Ultimately, successful microservices implementation is not just about technology but also about aligning with business goals, fostering a collaborative culture, and continuously improving processes.Want to know more? ğŸš¨ Job Offer or Scam? Beware of This Email Tactic!ğŸš¨ I recently received an email from Jennifer Brown offering me an internship or entry-level job opportunity. It seemed legitimate at firstâ€”they asked for my resume, reviewed it, and then rejected me. But what followed exposed the real motive behind this scheme!ğŸ”¹ Jennifer emailed me again, saying, "Your resume was rejected due to a low ATS score, but I can connect you with someone who can improve it."ğŸ”¹ When I agreed, she directed me to a Fiverr profile where I could "fix" my resumeâ€”for a price!ğŸ”¹ This wasnâ€™t the first time! A few weeks ago, I received a similar email from another person. I even reached out to their Fiverr contact, only to realize they were just selling paid resume reviews for $5â€“$10.This time, before I could fall for it again, I came across a LinkedIn post by Sarthak Mittal (CEO) exposing this scam (even the screenshot uploaded by Sarthak Mittal and the email I received have the same content written). Thatâ€™s when it all clicked!âš  Red Flags to Watch For:ğŸš¨ A rejection email followed by a paid service pitch.ğŸš¨ Being told your ATS score is too low and offered "help" for a fee.ğŸš¨ Recruiters redirecting you to Fiverr or paid platforms.ğŸš¨ Different names but the same tactics and email formats.ğŸ’¡ Lesson Learned? Never pay for job applications or resume fixes unless youâ€™ve done your own research! There are plenty of free AI tools to improve your resume. Donâ€™t let scammers profit off your job search struggles.Have you received similar emails? Letâ€™s spread awareness and expose these scams together! Share your experiences in the comments. ğŸ”ğŸ’¬hashtag#EmailScam hashtag#JobScam hashtag#ScamAlert hashtag#CareerFraud hashtag#ResumeScam hashtag#ATSScam hashtag#StayAware hashtag#LinkedInCommunity
